title-group.article-title: Kernel Earth Mover's Distance for EEG Classification

article-meta.aff: 1Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology (IUST), Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Reza Daliri, Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology (IUST), Narmak 16846-13114, Tehran, Iran Email: daliri@iust.ac.ir

abstract.p: Here, we propose a new kernel approach based on the earth mover's distance (EMD) for electroencephalography (EEG) signal classification. The EEG time series are first transformed into histograms in this approach. The distance between these histograms is then computed using the EMD in a pair-wise manner. We bring the distances into a kernel form called kernel EMD. The support vector classifier can then be used for the classification of EEG signals. The experimental results on the real EEG data show that the new kernel method is very effective, and can classify the data with higher accuracy than traditional methods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: EEG has attracted a lot of attention from researchers due to its ability to record neural activities in a non-invasive manner, its good temporal resolution, and low cost of the system. These properties make EEG a useful tool for clinical and also for brain computer interface (BCI) applications. Some of its clinical applications, widely studied in the literature, are epilepsy and seizure detection from EEG time series recordings. We review some of the approaches that have been used for the classification of EEG signals.

Chaovalitwongse and Pardalos 1 proposed a dynamic time-warping kernel for the classification of normal and preseizure activity from EEG signals. They used chaotic analysis for quantifying the brain dynamics in EEG signals. The short-term maximum Lyapunov exponent and angular frequency were the measurements used. In Ref 2 , wavelet feature extraction was applied to the EEG signals, and several experts used neural networks for the diagnosis of epilepsy. The signals were divided into subbands, using discrete wavelet transform (DWT), and some features were extracted from each subband for the classification of normal participants with epilepsy. Polat et al 3 proposed a hybrid artificial immune system for the classification of EEG signals. They used a combination of fuzzy resource allocation mechanism, principal component analysis (PCA), and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) in their hybrid system. FFT was applied for the feature extraction phase, then the dimensionality was reduced using PCA, and finally the reduced features were classified, using the artificial immune system classifier with fuzzy resource allocation. The same authors proposed a hybrid system, based on FFT and decision tree classifier for epileptiform EEG classification. 4 In Ref 5 , the diagnostic accuracy of the recurrent neural networks was evaluated for analyzing EEG signals. The features used for classification were extracted using the Lyapunov exponents computed based on the estimation of local Jacobi matrices. Several statistical features were then used to reduce the features extracted from the Lyapunov exponents. These features were fed to an Elman recurrent neural network for classification.

Kernel methods have been considered for solving many classification problems in recent years, and they have been very successful in many domains, including EEG classification. Some of these methods are described briefly. Garg et al 6 applied 2 kernel functions, namely the mahalanobis and multilayer Perceptron kernels, on EEG signals for sleep scoring systems. They compared results with polynomial and radial basis function kernels for support vector machines (SVM). They considered the radial basis function (RBF) kernel to be a better choice for this application.

In Ref 7 , a Riemannian-based kernel for EEG classification was proposed for BCI application. The comparison with other kernel methods on the BCI competition data set (motor imagery data set) showed that the proposed method worked better without doing spatial filtering.

Xu et al 8 improved the performance of hidden Markov model (HMM) for EEG classification using a kernel-based approach. They showed that the kernel-based HMM worked better than the original HMM for motor imagery classification using the EEG signals.

Several kernel-based methods were investigated for the task of epilepsy diagnosis using the EEG signals. 9 The kernels methods used were standard SVM, Lagrangian SVM, least squares SVM, smooth SVM, proximal SVM, and relevance vector machines. For epilepsy diagnosis the standard and least square SVM obtained more consistent results.

Another kernel method for EEG analysis was proposed by Lee et al. 10 A kernel nonnegative matrix factorization was introduced for extracting spectral features from the time–frequency analysis of EEG signals. The proposed method was tested on EEG databases from the BCI competition and it obtained good results.
We propose a new method based on EMD for EEG classification, and we show that the proposed approach is very effective when compared to previous ones.

sec.title: Signature of EEG Signals
sec.p: Before analyzing EEG signals, we used a preprocessing step to remove noise from the data 11 . Each recorded time series signal was divided into segments to properly account for possible nonstationarities in the EEGs. DWT was then applied to each segment to extract spectral representation of each segment. Different wavelet types were used; the Daubechies wavelet of order 4 (db4) was best to detect changes in EEG signals. 2 We also used the same wavelet type for extracting spectral representation of the EEG signals. This leads to decomposition of the original signal into 5 different bands D1 to D5 and 1 final approximation A5. These bands were used to create the histogram of EEG signals. The histogram of wavelet coefficients in each subband was then created, and these histograms were used as a signature for the EEG segment representation. We put all these histograms together to create a single histogram for each EEG segment (the histograms were concatenated to form a single histogram). Now, for the classification of the EEG signals, we need to compute the distance between these histograms. A proper metric for this aim is EMD, which we briefly explain in the following section.

sec.title: Earth Mover's Distance
sec.p:
EMD was first introduced by Rubner et al 12 as a metric for distributions, signatures, and histograms. It is defined as the minimum amount of work that is needed to make one distribution similar to another. This is to solve a transportation problem, using a bipartite graph, where in one side are the consumers' nodes and in the other the producers' nodes. Having 2 distributions or histograms of f 1 and f 2 to solve the transportation problem, one is considered the supplier and the other the consumer. There is a cost of shipment of a unit of supply to a consumer (Cij ). The complexity of the original EMD distance is high, and is in the order of supercubic which makes it inappropriate for large histograms. Ling and his colleague proposed a method for computing the EMD distance between the histograms with lower complexity. 13 This method uses the L 1 norm or Manhattan metric, as the ground distance for computing the distance between histograms. They showed that the proposed distance works very well for computer vision applications. To reduce the complexity of the method, we used the same distance previously proposed 13 .

sec.title: Kernel EMD
sec.p:
Having computed EMD between the 2 histograms derived from the original EEG signals, we can bring it into a kernel form to enable the use of SVM for classification. EMD is a metric if the ground distance for computing the EMD is a metric, and if the histograms are normalized before computing the EMD. 12,14 Having these conditions, we can create a positive definite kernel. sec.title: Support Vector Machines for Classification
sec.p:
Successful classifiers developed during past decades is SVM. The power of SVM is its good generalization. In the simplest form, it can classify the data into 2 classes in a 2-dimensional space with a linear function. In the linearly separable case, the training phase of SVM finds the linear function of the form of f(X) = WTX + b in such a way that it maximizes the margin between the 2 classes. Using optimization tools, it finds the samples that are closest to the line separating the 2 classes (called support vectors). At the same time, it finds the line in such a way that it maximizes the margin between the support vectors and the linear function. This concept can be easily generalized to the cases where the data are represented in higher dimensions, and to the cases where a nonlinear function is used to separate the data. Different kernel models can be used in the context of SVM classification. The simplest form of the kernels is a linear kernel which considers the dot product between each 2 samples: K(x,y) = x.y; while other nonlinear types of kernels are also used, like the polynomial kernel (K(x,y) = (x.y) d in which d is the degree of polynomial) and radial basis function (

Several approaches have also been proposed to consider the multiclass classification using the SVM. One method is one-against-one, 15,16 which creates C(C − 1)/2 hyperplanes for the C-class classification problem. Each hyperplane is created by considering the data for each pair of classes. Another widely used approach is the one-against-all, 17 which considers each class versus all other remaining classes and, therefore, creates a hyperplane for each class versus the others (in total C hyper-planes are created for C-class problem). There are several other options to extend the SVM to solve multiclass classification problems, including the all-together methods 18 and the directed acyclic graph. 19 Details of different approaches have previously been published. 20
For our experiments, we used A library for Support Vector Machines (LIBSVM), 21 which supports multiclass classification problems.

The data used for the experiments come from a public database available at the Epilepsy Center at the University of Bonn, Germany. 11 There are 5 sets of EEG signals, each including 100-single-channel EEG segments of 23.6 seconds duration. These sets are labeled A to E. The 2 first sets (A and B) are data collected from 5 healthy participants. These are surface EEG recordings. Data were collected while the participants were in a relaxed condition with eyes open (set A, Figure 1A) or closed (set B, Figure 1B). The remaining sets are the EEG data collected from 5 patients. Data in set D (Figure 1D) were collected from within the epileptogenic zone and data in set C (Figure 1C) were obtained from the hippocampal formation of the opposite hemisphere of the participants' brains. The data in these 2 sets were recorded during seizure-free periods, while data in set E (Figure 1E) come from seizure activity. Data were sampled at a rate of 173.61 Hz, which creates 4097 data points for each segment. The data were bandpass filtered from 0.53 to 40 Hz.

sec.title: Experimental Results
sec.p: We performed several experiments to show the ability of the proposed method of EEG classification.

sec.title: Classifying the 2 Groups of Data
sec.p:
In some of the studies, just 2 sets of data were used for the experiments. We intended to distinguish patients with epilepsy from healthy participants, using the EEG. These studies used sets A and E. Ten-fold cross-validation was used for the evaluation of accuracy. Data were divided into 10 separate equal folds and each time 9-folds were used for training, and the remaining fold was used for the test. The evaluation was repeated until all folds were considered. sec.title: Classifying the 3 Groups of Data
sec.p: In a previous paper a subset of the data was used for the classification of EEG signals. 5 Sets A, D, and E from the full sets were selected, and the performance of classification was reported for this subset. Eight hundred samples per class (2400 samples in total) were used as the training set, and the same number of samples was applied for the test. 5 Results have been evaluated for specificity, sensitivity, and accuracy of the classification. Specificity is defined as the number of healthy segments classified correctly by the total number of healthy segments. The sensitivity has been considered for 2 cases (1) for the seizure-free epileptogenic zone segments, which are defined as the number of seizure-free epileptogenic zone segments correctly identified divided by the total number of seizure-free epileptogenic zone segments, and (2) for the epileptic seizure segments that are defined as the number of epileptic seizure segments correctly classified over the total number of epileptic seizure segments. The cross-validation strategy, as discussed before, was used for the evaluation of the results (Table 3). Our proposed approach outperforms the previous method. 5

sec.title: Computational Complexity
sec.p: The main computational load of the proposed algorithm is related to computing the EMD between the 2 histograms, derived from the EEG signals. The original EMD distance proposed by Rubner et al 12 has supercubic complexity, which has the order of O(N3) when we have N bins for the histograms. We have used the EMD distance proposed by Ling et al. 13 This method used L 1 norm as the ground distance for computing the distance between the histograms. As mentioned previously, 13 this algorithm has the complexity of O(N2) which is much faster than the original EMD. 13

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We have proposed a new kernel method for the classification of EEG signals. In this approach, we first created a histogram from each sequence of EEG signals in each class. The proposed kernel method is based on the EMD, which is a proper distance between the distributions, signatures, and histograms. The main idea of this distance comes from the transportation problem, which considers the distributions as suppliers and consumers. It measures the minimum amount of work needed to transform one signature to the other. After computing the distance between the histograms using the EMD, we form a kernel of these pair-wise distances called kernel EMD. The SVMs can then be used to classify the data. The results show that the proposed kernel approach is very useful in EEG signal classification, and can be used for BCI and clinical applications.
